“I generally eschew conspiracy theories under the rubric that little explained by conspiracy cannot as well be explained by incompetence and that the occurrence of stupid is vastly more common than the occurrence of evil in the hearts and minds of men.”

There are members of the press who have access to @SpeakerPelosi and @StenyHoyer. Never once have reporters asked leadership why, when presented with two options, they chose to drag 218+ (unmasked!) members of congress into the chamber together instead of taking a recorded vote.

We know they were more afraid of transparency than the virus because Pelosi was faced with 2 options that day: allow members to come in and vote one at a time OR call at least 218 members of Congress in the chamber simultaneously to show that a quorum was present to avoid a vote.

It’s true that Congress, having enough members in attendance to pass the bill, then refused to take a recorded vote. In that refusal, they exposed that they were more afraid of being accountable to voters for that bill than they were of the virus. How do we know?

The press regularly says my effort failed. Then why did Congress come to work that day? If not for my insistence, Congress would have set two bad precedents that day: ignoring the Constitution due to a virus, and telegraphing to all Americans that’s it’s OK not to work.

Someone has plans to make the SARS-CoV-2 vaccine mandatory. There’s no other reason to explain why they are testing it on children right now.

@sharon_ringel Wearing the mask is a strategy to delay the point at which most of us are eventually exposed to the virus. Not a strategy to stop most of us from being exposed to the virus.

A lot of people keep forgetting that “flatten the curve” is/was about slowing the spread of COVID — not stopping the spread and not reducing the number of people who eventually get infected. It is/was about avoiding overwhelming medical resources until herd immunity is reached.

There is no authority in the Constitution that authorizes the government to stick a needle in you against your will, force you to wear a face mask, or track your daily movements.

Perhaps WV under-reported and/or NJ over-reported, but there’s at least a factor-of-10 difference in likelihood of dying from COVID, based on residency.

Observations like this aren’t frequently in the news, yet people are rationally factoring them into their personal decisions.

You were 32.6 times more likely to die of COVID if you lived in New Jersey vs. West Virginia (since the outbreak began until today).
